speaker: alex
text: Welcome back to Claude Code Mastery. I'm Alex, and today we're diving into customization. How to make Claude Code work exactly the way you need for your specific projects.

speaker: jamie
text: I'm Jamie, and I've been wondering about this. Every project has its own conventions, quirks, and requirements. Can Claude adapt to that?

speaker: alex
text: Absolutely. By the end of this episode, you'll know how to configure Claude Code with project-specific instructions, set up permissions, and customize its behavior for your workflow.

speaker: jamie
text: I've heard about a CLAUDE.md file. What's that?

speaker: alex
text: CLAUDE.md is a special file you can put in your project root that contains instructions for Claude. When Claude Code starts in that directory, it reads this file to understand your project's context and conventions.

speaker: jamie
text: Like a README but for Claude?

speaker: alex
text: Exactly! It's documentation that Claude uses to work better with your codebase. You can include information about your architecture, coding standards, testing requirements, and anything else Claude should know.

speaker: jamie
text: What kinds of things should go in there?

speaker: alex
text: Project overview: what the project does, its main technologies. Architectural decisions: why you structured things a certain way. Coding conventions: naming patterns, formatting rules. Common gotchas: things that might trip up someone new to the project.

speaker: jamie
text: So Claude reads it like a new team member would?

speaker: alex
text: Right. Think about what you'd tell a new developer on day one. That's what goes in CLAUDE.md.

speaker: jamie
text: Can you give specific examples?
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Sure. You might write: "This is a Next.js application with TypeScript. We use the App Router, not Pages Router. All API routes are in app/api. Database queries go through Prisma."
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Architecture overview.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Then coding conventions: "We use camelCase for functions, PascalCase for components. All components should have TypeScript props interfaces. Prefer async/await over promise chains."
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Style guidance.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Testing requirements: "All new features need tests. We use Jest with React Testing Library. Run tests with npm run test before committing."
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Process requirements.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: And project-specific knowledge: "The auth module was written by a contractor and is complex. Ask questions before modifying it. The config in legacy-config.js is deprecated but still used by some features."
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Tribal knowledge captured in writing.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. All that context that lives in senior developers' heads, written down for Claude.
chapter: SEGMENT 2: WHAT TO INCLUDE IN CLAUDE.MD (5 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Can I have different configurations for different contexts?

speaker: alex
text: Yes! Claude Code has a hierarchy of configuration. Global settings apply everywhere. Project settings in CLAUDE.md override globals. And you can have directory-specific settings too.

speaker: jamie
text: Give me an example of where that's useful.

speaker: alex
text: Say you work on multiple projects. Globally, you might set your preferred response length and formatting. But one project uses Python with specific linting rules, another uses TypeScript with different conventions. Each project's CLAUDE.md captures those specifics.

speaker: jamie
text: So I don't have to reconfigure for each project?

speaker: alex
text: Right. Claude automatically picks up the right context based on where you're working.

speaker: jamie
text: What about controlling what Claude can do?
chapter: SEGMENT 4: SETTING ALLOWED AND DISALLOWED TOOLS (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: You can configure which tools Claude can use. Maybe in a production environment, you want to restrict file writes. Or you want to prevent certain bash commands from running.
chapter: SEGMENT 4: SETTING ALLOWED AND DISALLOWED TOOLS (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: How do I set those restrictions?
chapter: SEGMENT 4: SETTING ALLOWED AND DISALLOWED TOOLS (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: In your CLAUDE.md or configuration files, you can specify allowed tools and disallowed tools. For example, you might allow Read and Grep but disallow Bash in a sensitive repository.
chapter: SEGMENT 4: SETTING ALLOWED AND DISALLOWED TOOLS (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: That's useful for security-conscious environments.
chapter: SEGMENT 4: SETTING ALLOWED AND DISALLOWED TOOLS (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. Enterprise teams often lock down what Claude can do to match their security policies.
chapter: SEGMENT 4: SETTING ALLOWED AND DISALLOWED TOOLS (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Can I restrict specific commands within Bash?
chapter: SEGMENT 4: SETTING ALLOWED AND DISALLOWED TOOLS (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Yes. You can say "allow npm commands but not rm" or "only allow git commands." Fine-grained control is possible.
chapter: SEGMENT 4: SETTING ALLOWED AND DISALLOWED TOOLS (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: You mentioned permissions earlier in the series. How do they relate to project configuration?

speaker: alex
text: Permissions can be configured at the project level. You might set up a preset that says "always allow file reads in this project without prompting" while keeping write permissions manual.

speaker: jamie
text: So I don't have to approve every single read?

speaker: alex
text: Right. Once you trust Claude with certain operations in a project, you can streamline them. But you can keep prompts for higher-risk operations like writes or command execution.

speaker: jamie
text: Balancing speed and safety.

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. As you build trust with Claude in a project, you might loosen restrictions. Start tight, then open up as you get comfortable.

speaker: jamie
text: Can I give Claude ongoing instructions beyond CLAUDE.md?

speaker: alex
text: Yes. You can set custom instructions that persist across conversations. Things like "always explain your reasoning" or "prefer functional programming patterns" or "be very conservative with changes."

speaker: jamie
text: Where do these get set?

speaker: alex
text: In Claude Code's settings or in project configuration. They're persistent, so you don't have to repeat them each session.

speaker: jamie
text: What kinds of instructions are most useful?

speaker: alex
text: Communication style preferences: verbose explanations versus terse responses. Technical preferences: certain patterns you always want or never want. Workflow preferences: always run tests after edits, always show diffs before changes.

speaker: jamie
text: Shaping how Claude works.

speaker: alex
text: Right. You're training Claude to be the kind of collaborator you want.

speaker: jamie
text: What about environment setup? Like making sure Claude knows about dependencies?

speaker: alex
text: Claude reads your dependency files automatically. Package.json, requirements.txt, Cargo.toml. It understands what's available in your project.

speaker: jamie
text: But what about environment variables or local setup?

speaker: alex
text: You can document those in CLAUDE.md. "This project requires a DATABASE_URL environment variable." "Run docker-compose up before testing." Claude will know what's expected.

speaker: jamie
text: Does Claude have access to my environment variables?

speaker: alex
text: Only if you share them. Claude Code doesn't automatically read your environment. But if relevant, you can tell Claude what variables are set.

speaker: jamie
text: Good for security.

speaker: alex
text: Right. Secrets stay secret unless you explicitly share them.

speaker: jamie
text: What about telling Claude how to build and run the project?
chapter: SEGMENT 8: BUILD AND RUN CONFIGURATION (3 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Include that in CLAUDE.md. "Build with npm run build. Run development server with npm run dev. Run production build with npm run start."
chapter: SEGMENT 8: BUILD AND RUN CONFIGURATION (3 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: So Claude knows the commands.
chapter: SEGMENT 8: BUILD AND RUN CONFIGURATION (3 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. Then when you say "start the dev server," Claude knows to run npm run dev rather than guessing.
chapter: SEGMENT 8: BUILD AND RUN CONFIGURATION (3 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What if the commands are non-standard?
chapter: SEGMENT 8: BUILD AND RUN CONFIGURATION (3 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Even more important to document. "We use a custom build script: ./scripts/build.sh with arguments for environment."
chapter: SEGMENT 8: BUILD AND RUN CONFIGURATION (3 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What about sharing configuration across a team?

speaker: alex
text: CLAUDE.md can be committed to your repository. Everyone who uses Claude Code in that project gets the same context and instructions.

speaker: jamie
text: Consistency across the team.

speaker: alex
text: Right. It's especially valuable when you have a team using Claude Code together. Everyone gets the same guardrails and guidance.

speaker: jamie
text: What about personal preferences that differ per developer?

speaker: alex
text: Those can be in your global configuration, which isn't committed. So team settings in CLAUDE.md, personal preferences in your local config.

speaker: jamie
text: Best of both worlds.

speaker: jamie
text: I work on several projects. How do I manage that?

speaker: alex
text: Each project has its own CLAUDE.md with project-specific configuration. When you cd into a project and start Claude Code, it automatically picks up that project's settings.

speaker: jamie
text: Seamless context switching.

speaker: alex
text: Right. You don't have to remember to load different configs. It just works.

speaker: jamie
text: What if projects share some configuration?

speaker: alex
text: Common patterns can go in your global config. Only project-specific details go in CLAUDE.md. Keep each CLAUDE.md focused on what's unique to that project.

speaker: jamie
text: How do I know what to configure?

speaker: alex
text: Start minimal. Use Claude Code on your project and notice friction points. When you find yourself repeatedly correcting Claude about something, add it to CLAUDE.md.

speaker: jamie
text: Let pain points guide configuration.

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. Don't try to think of everything upfront. Let your actual usage reveal what needs to be documented.

speaker: jamie
text: And update it over time?

speaker: alex
text: Yes. CLAUDE.md should evolve with your project. New architectural decisions, new conventions, new team knowledge. Keep it current.

speaker: jamie
text: What do most teams configure?

speaker: alex
text: Almost everyone documents build and test commands. That's table stakes. Most document coding conventions, especially if they're non-obvious.

speaker: jamie
text: What else?

speaker: alex
text: Architecture overviews for complex projects. Security-sensitive areas that need extra care. Integration points with external services. Deployment requirements.

speaker: jamie
text: The stuff that's hard to figure out from code alone.

speaker: alex
text: Right. If understanding requires context beyond the code itself, it belongs in CLAUDE.md.

speaker: jamie
text: What are your tips for effective configuration?
chapter: SEGMENT 13: TIPS FOR GOOD CONFIGURATION (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: First, be specific. "Follow best practices" isn't helpful. "Use early returns instead of nested ifs" is specific and actionable.
chapter: SEGMENT 13: TIPS FOR GOOD CONFIGURATION (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Concrete over abstract.
chapter: SEGMENT 13: TIPS FOR GOOD CONFIGURATION (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Second, explain why, not just what. "We use dependency injection because it makes testing easier" helps Claude understand the purpose, not just the rule.
chapter: SEGMENT 13: TIPS FOR GOOD CONFIGURATION (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Context for decisions.
chapter: SEGMENT 13: TIPS FOR GOOD CONFIGURATION (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: Third, update when things change. Outdated configuration is worse than no configuration. If you refactor something, update CLAUDE.md.
chapter: SEGMENT 13: TIPS FOR GOOD CONFIGURATION (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: Keep it fresh.
chapter: SEGMENT 13: TIPS FOR GOOD CONFIGURATION (4 minutes)

speaker: alex
text: And fourth, test your configuration. Work with Claude on the project and see if it follows your guidelines. Refine based on what actually happens.
chapter: SEGMENT 13: TIPS FOR GOOD CONFIGURATION (4 minutes)

speaker: jamie
text: What should listeners practice?

speaker: alex
text: Create a CLAUDE.md for one of your projects. Include at least: a project overview, build and test commands, two or three coding conventions, and one piece of architectural knowledge that's not obvious from the code.

speaker: jamie
text: A starter configuration.

speaker: alex
text: Then use Claude Code on that project and see how the configuration affects Claude's behavior. Iterate from there.

speaker: jamie
text: Great episode on configuration. What's coming up?

speaker: alex
text: Episode eight is about advanced prompting techniques. How to communicate with Claude effectively to get the best possible results.

speaker: jamie
text: The art of asking.

speaker: alex
text: Exactly. See you in episode eight!

speaker: jamie
text: Happy configuring!
